title: Andrew Ridgeley admits terror that George Michael would die of AIDS
text:

Andrew Ridgeley, who performed in Wham! with the late pop star George Michael , has lifted the lid on the star's troubled past in a new tell-all book.

He admitted that when George first came out to him in 1983, he was terrified this might mean he would become victim to the AIDS epidemic that was killing the gay community.

In his book, Wham! George & Me, Andrew, 56, wrote: “A terrible additional worry was the emergence of AIDS.

“I know I wasn’t the only friend of George’s who worried about him during that uncertain, frightening period.”

Andrew recalled that he was surprised when George came out, but said he just wanted George to be happy - in an era where homophobia was rife.

(Image: Getty Images)

George had called Andrew into a room with his friend and backing singer, Shirlie Holliman.

“When I walked across the hallway to George’s room, Shirlie was already there, perched on a large sofa in the suite. George was still in bed. He smiled as I came in", wrote Andrew.

“The mood in the room was so relaxed and familiar, yet what George was about to reveal was clearly a big deal for him.

“‘I didn’t know whether to tell you this’, he said, looking across at Shirlie, 'but I’m going to. I’m gay’.”

Shirlie, who already knew, had reassured George that Andrew would not have an issue with George coming out, after he expressed fears to her.

George's partner Anselmo Feleppa tragically died from AIDs in 1993.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: Redferns)

Andrew wrote: “It had devastated him but he’d been unable to discuss it in public.

Had he spoken out earlier, who knows how differently things might have played out.”

George died from heart and liver disease at age 53, three years ago on Christmas Day 2016.

Andrew said of George's untimely passing: "He seemed to be in good health at the time and there are conflicting reports surrounding that night that preceded his passing.

"It now seems as if we may never know what really happened.

“We don’t like our lives being monitored, so when someone dies alone, perhaps there are always answers that remain out of reach.

“It still feels uncomfortable though. God knows what it must be like for George’s family.”

(Image: AFP)

In 1998, the Careless Whisper singer was forced to come out after being arrested in Beverly Hills for soliciting sex in a public toilet.

Andrew also revealed that he and George had a saucy history of reading pornographic magazines together in secret in a field by George's house, when they were teenagers.

George then persuaded Andrew to visit an adult cinema with him, but they were put off by other men in the audience treating the viewing as an “interactive experience” by attempting to perform sex acts on themselves.

The pair then tried to watch a live sex show together, but soon changed their minds after realising they had to pay £20 for drinks.

Wham! George & Me, by Andrew Ridgeley, is out now.
description: George Michael's former bandmate Andrew Ridgeley has spoken out about his fears the star would die from AIDS
